msIdentifier.repository: Perne Library: on long-term deposit at Cambridge University Library

summary.seg: Peterhouse MS 178 contains a compilation of medical and scientific texts written in the 14th century by a single scribe and extensively corrected and annotated by that scribe and other medieval annotators throughout the volume. The manuscript is comprised of two codicological units (ff. 1r-244v and 225r-310v, both written by the same scribe, but prepared with a different mise-en-page in each unit, i.e., in single-column format for ff. 1-244 and in double-column format ff. 225-310. The scribe writes a calligraphic although somewhat error-prone gothic rotunda throughout and he generally adds his corrections in the margin in that same gothic rotunda hand and encloses his corrections within red frames. Rod Thomson, in his catalogue record for Peterhouse MS 178 states that the manuscript was written 'by a single Low Countries scribe', presumably based on a palaeographical assessment of the volume; in addition, as Thomson also points out, the manuscript must have been in England (if it was not written here by a scribe trained in the Low Countries), because there are marginal notes in English in 14th century hands.

In his Catalogue of the Peterhouse manuscripts, Thomson drew attention to one of the 14th-century annotators, since he noticed similar annotations in three Peterhouse manuscripts, MSS 109, 150 and 178. After careful comparison of these annotations, Thomson cautiously suggested that these marginalia could be by the hand of the former master of Peterhouse, Ralph HolbecheHolbeche, Ralph (d. c. 1373-1374). These annotations are in a 14th century Anglicana script, and Peterhouse MS 178 is the most lightly annotated of the three volumes: see ff. 45v ('Nota Elmam'), 51v ('Lok wel'), 66v ('Nota Ryde ... ... ...'), 125r ('Scharp lok þis') and 170r ('Lo Robyn'). As Thomson notes, these annotations, and those in Peterhouse MSS 109 and 150 appear to be teaching notes, with their author referring to his students with frequent interjections of 'Lo [name]' or '[name] lok þis'. For more information, readers are encouraged to consult Thomson's Catalogue descriptions of Peterhouse MSS 109 and 150 and in particular that of MS 109, where Thomson describes a note on f. 252v signed 'Rad Holbech' which appears to be in the same hand as the teaching-annotations in that volume and MSS 150 and 178.

References:
R. M. Thomson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse, Cambridge (Cambridge: D.S. Brewer, 2016), nos 109, 150, 178 Venn: ACAD (no number, search 'Holbeche')

Dr Sarah Gilbert
Project Cataloguer for the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries Project
Cambridge University Library

msContents.textLang: Latin, with occasional notes in Middle English

msItem.title: Tabule magistri Richardi cum commento magistri Iohannis de Sancto Paulo
msItem.author: Richardus Anglicus (fl. 1180)
msItem.rubric: 1r Incipiunt tabule magistri Richardi cum commento .desuper. quas compilauit magister idem
msItem.incipit:
1r Columna prima
de emagoga
Cassia fistula
msItem.explicit:
9r Saluiam
Castoreum
msItem.finalRubric: 9r Expliciunt tabule cum commento magistri Johannis de sancto paulo
msItem.note: According to Thomson, Peterhouse MS 178 contains the only copy of this text.
The attribution of this text to Richardus Anglicus is not confirmed by any other sources.

listBibl.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse, Cambridge (Cambridge: D.S. Brewer, 2016)

msItem.title: Commentary on the Tabula remediorum Salernita
msItem.author: Bernard of Provence
msItem.rubric: 9v Incipiunt Glosule tabule salerni cum commento
msItem.incipit: 9v Omnis practicus est theoricus sed non conuertitur . salernus est practicus . ergo theoricus
msItem.explicit: 37r sermonis igitur lasciuientis riuulum pregnantem hic stagnare faciamus feliciter
msItem.finalRubric: 37r Deo gratias Explicit commentum magistri Richardi

listBibl.bibl: Edited, not from this MS in Collectio Salernitana, 5 (1859), pp. 233-328
eTK 1001A (t0192190000) where it is posited as being by Richard of Wendover

msItem.title: De crisi
msItem.author: Richardus Anglicus (fl. 1180)
msItem.rubric: 37v Incipit de crisi que non fit in nisi in egritudinibus uelocis motus
msItem.incipit: 37v Crisis non fit nisi in egritudinibus uelocis motus et ille dicuntur acute cum quibus est timor
msItem.explicit: 40r et ista sunt ad salutem secundum quod dicit G. in libro de crisi
msItem.note: According to Thomson, Peterhouse MS 178 contains the only copy of this text.
The attribution of this text to Richardus Anglicus is not confirmed by any other sources.

msItem.title: De phlebotomia
msItem.rubric: 40r Incipit in quibus egritudinibus competat flebotomia
msItem.incipit: 40r Requirendum est nobis breuiter in quibus egritudinibus flebotomia competit . et de quibus uenis . nota quod minutio quaedam sit per metatesim quadam per antipasim . per metatesim dicitur
msItem.explicit: 42v sciatica quia eius incisio ualet contra sciaticam passionem
msItem.finalRubric: 42v Flebotomia magistri rogeri Richardi hic explicit
msItem.note: This text is attributed to Roger of Salerno in Thomson's Catalogue, but the Voigts article about this treatise does not identify an author of this text. The final rubric initially attributed the text to a 'Roger' (presumably Roger of Salerno Ruggero Frugardo, active 12th century ), but the scribe then corrected the attribution to 'Richardi' (presumably Richardus Anglicus (fl. 1180) Richardus Anglicus ca. 1162-1242). In other manuscripts, this text is attributed to Henry of WinchesterHenricus Wintoniensis ca. um 1305/16.

listBibl.bibl: See E. Wickersheimer, Dictionnaire biographique des médicins en France au moyen âge p. 697
R. M. Thomson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse, Cambridge (Cambridge: D.S. Brewer, 2016), esp. p. 105

Edited (not from this MS) and discussed in L. E. Voigts, and M. R. McVaugh, 'A Latin Technical Phlebotomy and Its Middle English Translation', Transactions of the American Philosophical Society, 74.2 (1984), pp. 1-69 [doi.org/10.2307/1006388]

msItem.title: Signa (Micrologus, part 5)
msItem.author: Richardus Anglicus (fl. 1180)
msItem.incipit: 42v De signis remotionis et propinquitatis et status
43v Finis medicine laudabilis existis . Cum auctor in singulis ualitudininbus
msItem.explicit: 82v et praecipue cum lingue nigredine signum est mortale
msItem.note: The Micrologus of Richardus Anglicus (fl. 1180) has not survived in a single complete manuscript copy with a prologue and the parts arranged 1-5; nevertheless one or more of its parts are extant in various combinations in over 30 manuscripts. See Sharpe, Handlist, pp. 468-474 for further information.

listBibl.bibl: Partially edited in H. H. Beusing, Das Leben und Werke des Ricardus Anglicus (PhD thesis, Leipzig, 1922), esp. pp. 32-42

title.supplied: Tractatus febrium et aliarum passionum diuersarum

msItem.author: Richardus Anglicus (fl. 1180)
msItem.rubric: 82v Incipit tractatus febrium et aliarum passionum diuersarum a magistro Richardo compositus hac enim practica obtima est et mirabilis
msItem.incipit: 82v Ex universalibus in quibus consistist ars medicinalis et finitur elitiuntur
msItem.explicit: 129r cum salle et melle superpositum confert
msItem.note: According to Thomson, Peterhouse MS 178 contains the only copy of this text.

listBibl.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse, Cambridge (Cambridge: D.S. Brewer, 2016), esp. p. 105

msItem.author: Richardus Anglicus (fl. 1180)
msItem.incipit: 129v Laxatiua solent multum laxando nocere . Sed tamen arcis opere nocumenta . potes remouere
129v Aloe est quia a prima litera incipit erit principium
msItem.explicit: 134v abiectum totum medium huius pisciculi pro una dosi accipias uel offeras et per uin cum optimo modo conficias
msItem.note: The Micrologus of Richardus Anglicus (fl. 1180) has not survived in a single complete manuscript copy with a prologue and the parts arranged 1-5; nevertheless one or more of its parts are extant in various combinations in over 30 manuscripts. See Sharpe, Handlist, pp. 468-474 for further information.

msItem.author: Richardus Anglicus (fl. 1180)
msItem.incipit: 135r tor de singulius humorum differenciis geminam
msItem.explicit: 142r ypostasim . in fundo et crassam
msItem.note: The Micrologus of Richardus Anglicus (fl. 1180) has not survived in a single complete manuscript copy with a prologue and the parts arranged 1-5; nevertheless one or more of its parts are extant in various combinations in over 30 manuscripts. See Sharpe, Handlist, pp. 468-474 for further information.

msItem.title: Anatomia (Micrologus, part 3)
msItem.author: Richardus Anglicus (fl. 1180)
msItem.incipit: 142r Galieno testante in Tegni Quicunque interiorum membrorum cognitor esse desiderat . ipsum in anathomia diligentem esse operet
msItem.explicit: 150v Qui cupit ars nostra materia per compendia scire . Hoc legat assidue nec potest oportet longius ire
msItem.note: The Micrologus of Richardus Anglicus (fl. 1180) has not survived in a single complete manuscript copy with a prologue and the parts arranged 1-5; nevertheless one or more of its parts are extant in various combinations in over 30 manuscripts. See Sharpe, Handlist, pp. 468-474 for further information.

listBibl.bibl: Edited (not from this MS) in K. Sudhoff, 'Der "Micrologus"-Text Der "Anatomia" Richards Des Engländers', Archiv Für Geschichte Der Medizin, 19.3 (1927), pp. 209–239

msItem.title: Prologue to the Micrologus
msItem.author: Richardus Anglicus (fl. 1180)
msItem.incipit:
150v Si quod agam solitum preter ueniam date cuncti
Nec uos offendat si noua grata canam
Suppositam modis retegit candelabra lucem
Ut sit commune quod fuit ante meum
Sicut odor nardi spirabit sermo rigardi
Splendet mircrologi lux Quasi flama rogi
150v Si uenerande uetustati sicut moderne nouitati . ex sola fuisset olim studiorum negociorum ue prolixitas
msItem.explicit: 151v Igitur ars prius insurget in causam que magis uiget . Dampnaque maiora releuet prius . inde minora
msItem.note: The Micrologus of Richardus Anglicus (fl. 1180) has not survived in a single complete manuscript copy with a prologue and the parts arranged 1-5; nevertheless one or more of its parts are extant in various combinations in over 30 manuscripts. See Sharpe, Handlist, pp. 468-474 for further information.

This text only survives in one other manuscript, Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, MS Lat. 6957, ff. 37rv; in BNF MS Lat. 6957, the poem at the opening of the prologue in Peterhouse MS 178 ('Si quod agam ... Quasi flama rogi') is at the end of the text.

listBibl.bibl: Printed from the BNF MS in K. Sudhoff, 'Richard der Engländer', Janus. Archives internationales pour l'histoire de la médecine et pour la géographie médicale 28 (1924, pp. 397-403
Partially edited in H. Hellriegel, diss. (Leipzig, 1934), pp. 9-10
R. M. Thomson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse, Cambridge (Cambridge: D.S. Brewer, 2016), esp. p. 105

msItem.author: Richardus Anglicus (fl. 1180)
msItem.incipit: 151v Acutarum egritudinum . alia est terciana de colera rubera
msItem.explicit: 193r cum succo anoglosse sed tamen utiliter adhibeatur primo flebotomia
msItem.note: The Micrologus of Richardus Anglicus (fl. 1180) has not survived in a single complete manuscript copy with a prologue and the parts arranged 1-5; nevertheless one or more of its parts are extant in various combinations in over 30 manuscripts. See Sharpe, Handlist, pp. 468-474 for further information.

msItem.title: De criticis diebus
msItem.author: Richardus Anglicus (fl. 1180)
msItem.incipit: 193r Creticorum uero dierum ypocrates duas rationes adinuenit . unam pertinarium aliam per quaternarium
msItem.explicit: 194r et hic est spatium ccclxv. dierum et ui. horarum
msItem.note: This appears to be the only surviving copy of this text.

msItem.title: De pulsibus
msItem.author: Richardus Anglicus (fl. 1180)
msItem.rubric: 194r Incipit de pulsibus secndum magistrum Richardum philosofum
msItem.incipit: 194r Pulsus est operatio uirtutis spiritualis
msItem.explicit: 201v uicina cordi et ei quod sunt iuxta cor Et hec sunt de pulsibus quod auctoritate antiquorum dicere proposuimus
msItem.finalRubric: 201v Explicit tractatus magistri Richardi de pulsibus
msItem.note: Also in Oxford, New College, MS 167 and a lost manuscript, Wroclaw, Biblioteka Uniwersytecka, Rehdigeriana (olim Biblioteka Miejska) 1302, for which a ?partial 19th century copy exists, Wroclaw, Biblioteka Uniwersytecka, M 1303 .

msItem.title: Text on pulses
msItem.incipit: 201v Et relique species . Diuersa genera pulsuum . auc iste in precedentibus posuit
msItem.explicit: 202r de inequali autem et inequale non hunc medium . in hoc conueniunt omnes auctores

msItem.title: Versus de ponderibus
msItem.incipit: 202r Collige triticeis medicine pondera granis . Grana quater quinque scrupulum pro pondere sume
msItem.explicit: 202r Librarum v. potis pondus mediare

msItem.title: Etymologiae 16:27 - De signis ponderum
msItem.author: Isidore of Seville
msItem.incipit: 202r Ponderis signa plerisque ignota errorem legentibus faciunt
msItem.explicit: 202r quod Graeci oxifalon vocant M M Graecum superposita .N. latina significat minam

msItem.title: De conferentibus et nocentibus
msItem.author: pseudo-Arnaldus de Villanova
msItem.rubric: 202v Incipiunt conferentie et primo de conferentiis cerebri
msItem.incipit: 202v Conferunt cerebro fetida in graui opilatione cerebri . in maiori apoplexia
msItem.explicit: 207r omnes carnes et pisces . per salem indurata et exiccati omne nimis uentosum
msItem.note: Similar to the version of this text in Cambridge, St John's College, MS D.24, ff. 349r-352r.
This text is often attributed to Arnaldus de Villanova Arnaldus, de Villanova, -1311 , but it is generally not thought to be one of this authentic works.
Note that this version of the text is not particularly close to the standard edition of the text printed in Lyon in 1504.

listBibl.bibl: Standard edition of the text is Hec sunt opera Arnaldi de Villanoua que in hoc volumine continentur, (François Fradin, Lyon, 1504), ff. 302r-313v

msItem.title: Addition to De conferentibus et nocentibus
msItem.incipit: 207r De nocumento ueneris . Nocet uenus omnibus arthriticis
msItem.explicit: 207r et sic de aliis intellige
msItem.note: The text from f. 207r ln 8. seq. to the bottom of f. 207r is treated by the scribe as part of De conferentibus et nocentibus, but the two sub-sections of text headed De nocumentio ueneris and De uiuamento veneris do not seem to be part of any other surviving copy of this text.

msItem.title: De modo medendi [Latin]
Capitula to De modo medendi
msItem.incipit: 207v De modo medendi quot et quibus modus medemur . De primo modo et prius secundum modu in quo continetur materia est preparatione potionandi
msItem.explicit: 208r De electuariis quibus proprie dari debeant et de laxativis

msItem.title: Capitula to De modo medendi
msItem.incipit: 208r In medendis corporibus et maxime purgandis uariis sepere molestamur in comodis
msItem.explicit: 220v et sic panset infirmus fit etiam alteratio tam cibis quam potibus quam medicinis conuentibus
msItem.note: Ends early at Renzi, IV:434.
Variously attributed to either Gerard of Cremona Gherardo, da Cremona, 1113 or 1114-1187 (c. 1113/1114 – 1187) or Gerard of Montpellier Gerard of Montpellier (13th century).

msItem.title: De conficiendis medicinis
msItem.author: Copho
msItem.incipit: 220v Executo modo medendi agendum est de modo conficiendi . ostendamus ergo quomodo deberant confici medicine
msItem.explicit: 224v quia magis dissoluerent quam consumerent et sic lederent

msItem.title: Quaestiones Salernitanae
msItem.incipit: 225r Queritur quare gallus facit in senectute et non in iuuentute et cuius ex ouo nascitur serpens qui moritur ex solo odore rute solutio . Gallus naturaliter est colericus
msItem.explicit: 263r et in eis enim concauitates sunt et calor et humiditas quia uermes generare ac nutrire possunt

listBibl.bibl: Edited as siglum 'P' in B. Lawn (ed.), The Prose Salernitan Questions: edited from a Bodleian manuscript (Auct. F.3.10): an anonymous collection dealing with science and medicine written by an Englishman c. 1200, with an appendix of ten related collections, Auctores Britannici Medii Aevi, 5 (London: Oxford University Press for the British Academy, 1979), esp. 'Appendix P' pp. xi, 204-261 and p. 108.

msItem.title: Extracts from works by Urso of Salerno
msItem.author: Urso of Salerno
msItem.rubric: 263r Incipit tractatus de coloribus secundum magister Ul’
msItem.incipit: 263r Tractaturi de coloribus primo quid sit color uideamus et quod sunt species coloris
msItem.explicit: 266r cum gustu per cipiatur magis compilationem rei declinat declarat substantia quam color
msItem.finalRubric: 266r Et hec de coloribus breuiter dicta sufficiant
msItem.note:
Similar arrangements of this text can be found in:
London, British Library, MS Royal 12.E.15, ff. 17r-18v
London, British Library, MS Sloane 1933, ff. 137v-138r
Vienna, Österreichische Nationalbibliothek, Cod. 5207, ff. 112v-116r
Includes recipes for iron gall ink and for various coloured pigments.

listBibl.bibl: Edited, not from this MS, in L. Thorndike, ‘Some Medieval Texts on Colours’, Ambix, 7.1 (1959), pp. 1–24 doi.org/10.1179/amb.1959.7.1.1

D. W. Singer, A. Anderson, R. Addis, Catalogue of Latin and Vernacular Alchemical Manuscripts in Great Britain and Ireland Dating from before the XVI Century, 3 vols (Brussels: Maurice Lamertin, 1928), II, p. 597, no. 877.1
M. Clarke, The Art of All Colours: Mediaeval Recipe Books for Painters and Illuminators (London: Archetype Publications, 2001), p. 64, no. 260

msItem.title: Unidentified text on odours and sense of smell
msItem.incipit: 266r amarum percepimus . tamen in instrumentis uisus puncturam et morsuram sentimus cum ibi colliria et huius apponimus . Alii dicebant nullo modo substantam rei percipi odore . Hanc ostendentes ratonem
msItem.explicit: 267r gustus non delectetur a tali sapore immutatus
msItem.note: Lacks rubric and perhaps opening words of the text.

listBibl.bibl: D. W. Singer, A. Anderson, R. Addis, Catalogue of Latin and Vernacular Alchemical Manuscripts in Great Britain and Ireland Dating from before the XVI Century, 3 vols (Brussels: Maurice Lamertin, 1928), II, p. 597, no. 877.2

msItem.title: Questiones magistri Lorentii
msItem.incipit: 267r Quidam in febre amisit memoriam litterarum Solutio . febris fuit in cerebro . uel in aliqua parte habente colligantiam cum cerebro
msItem.explicit: 275v Unde consumitur materia qua consumpta deficit febris
msItem.note: In his edition of the prose Salernitan questions, Lawn draws attention to the similarity of the versions of this text in this manuscript and in Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Auct. F.3.10, ff. 154r-161v . Lawn also suggests that this is the same text recorded as 'questiones Salernitane a magro loz composite' by M. R. James in Ancient Libraries, no. 1236, p. 342. According to Lawn (p. xvii) this 'magister Lorentius seems to be otherwise unknown in Salernitan literature'.

listBibl.bibl: Edited as siglum 'L' in B. Lawn (ed.), The Prose Salernitan Questions: edited from a Bodleian manuscript (Auct. F.3.10): an anonymous collection dealing with science and medicine written by an Englishman c. 1200, with an appendix of ten related collections, Auctores Britannici Medii Aevi, 5 (London: Oxford University Press for the British Academy, 1979), esp. 'Appendix Ba' and 'Appendix L' pp. xi, xvii, 156-203.

msItem.title: Tractatus de naturali philosophia
msItem.incipit: 275v Studentibus in naturali philosophia primo uidendum est quid sit exterior cognitio naturaliter philosophie
msItem.explicit: 310v quidam dicunt quod sicut ignis nex
msItem.note: According to Thomson, Peterhouse MS 178 contains the only copy of this text.
Ends imperfectly.

foliation.p: Early 21st-century foliation (incorporating some of the partial foliation of the 19th century).
foliation.note: Foliated in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the upper outer corner of the recto of each leaf.

foliation.p: This manuscript was previously understood to be composite, with Part 1 comprising the present ff. 1-224 and Part 2 comprising the present ff. 225-310; it seems that at some point while the manuscript was viewed as a composite volume it was given an additional foliation sequence which restarted at 'f. 1' at the present f. 225, and some folio designations in this sequence were added to the volume, i.e., folios '51' (for the present 275r) to '84' (for the present ff. 309r)
foliation.note: A deprecated foliation sequence in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the upper outer corner of the recto of some of the leaves towards the end of the manuscript - these foliation sigla have been struck through in pencil to indicate that they are no longer used.

foliation.p: Paginated as pp. 3-245 for the present leaves ff. 1r-122r)
foliation.note: Paginated in light brown ink in the typical medieval forms of Hindu-Arabic numerals in the upper outer corner of the recto and verso of each leaf from the present leaves ff. 1r-122r.

foliation.p: Paginated as pp. 244-395 for the present leaves ff. 121v-193r)
foliation.note: Paginated in drypoint in the medieval forms of Hindu-Arabic numerals in the centre of the upper margin of most leaves from ff. 121v-193r. This pagination sequence was in place before the loss of 5 leaves in Quire 12 between the present ff. 134v and 135r as this drypoint pagination sequence jumps from p. 270 (134v) to p. 281 (135r), which is consistent with the stubs and codicology that indicate the loss of 5 leaves from that quire. There is an error in this sequence at the present opening ff. 184v-185r which are drypoint-paginated as pp. 378-379, which is a repeat of the previous opening, ff. 183v-184r which are also (correctly within the context of this sequence) paginated as pp. 378-379. This pagination sequence can be quite difficult to see in normal (natural or artificial) lighting conditions, but there is a relatively clear example of p. 283 in this designation sequence on f. 136r.

collation.p:
A manuscript comprised of two codicological units (ff. 1-224 and 225r-310v) written by the same scribe, but prepared with a different mise-en-page in each unit, and the quires arranged in the following way:
Quires 1-1112 (ff. 1-132)
Quire 1212-5 (ff. 133-139: 3rd-7th leaves missing)
Quires 13-1712 (ff. 140-199)
Quire 184 (ff. 200-203)
Quire 1912 (ff. 204-215)
Quire 2010-1 (ff. 216-224: 10th leaf excised, probably blank) ;
Quires 21-2312 (ff. 225-260)
Quire 2414 (ff. 261-274)
Quires 25-2612 (ff. 275-298)
Quire 2710+1 (ff. 299-309: 1st leaf inserted)
Quire 28one (f. 310: perhaps originally a bifolium, with the 2nd leaf missing)
collation.formula: 1-1112 1212-5 (3rd-7th leaves missing) 13-1712 184 1912 2010-1 (10th excised, probably blank); 21-2312 2414 25-2612 2710+1 (1st leaf inserted) 28one (perhaps originally a bifolium, with the 2nd leaf missing)

signatures.p: Most leaf signatures trimmed away, but a 'vi' remains in the lower outer corner of the 6th leaf of Quire 19, i.e., f. 209r.
Quires have modern leaf signatures in pencil that seem to reflect an earlier belief that the manuscript might have been composite: a-i k-o þ 1-4 u 1-8.

catchwords.seg: Medieval catchwords in ink in the lower margin of the last verso of each quire, some partially trimmed away and many catchwords in the latter half of the volume enclosed in a red frame e.g., f. 175v.

supportDesc.condition: In good condition, although text near the gutter can be difficult to read as the fragility of the hinges restricts the maximum angle of opening. The leaves have been trimmed for rebinding with minor losses to marginal text and decoration throughout, see e.g., the outer margin of f. 280r. Minor rodent damage at the lower outer corner of the leaves in the final fifth of the volume.

layout.seg: Folios 1r-9r ruled in, frame and lines. Written in triple-column format for a capitula list, typically 33 lines to the column and written below top line.
Folios 9v-224v ruled in crayon, frame and lines. Written in single-column format, typically 33 lines to the page and written below top line.
Folios 225r-310v ruled in crayon, frame and lines. Written in double-column format, typically 33 lines to the column and written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in a northern textualis rotunda by a single scribe. R. M. Thomson describes the work as being that of a 'Low Countries scribe' and also notes that he 'corrects his work in the margins, cancelling the error and framing the correction in red.' Although the mise-en-page changes from single- to double-column format at f. 225r, the same scribe is resonsible for the entirety of the volume and hand, rubrication pattern, and decoration are consistent throughout.

listBibl.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse, Cambridge (Cambridge: D.S. Brewer, 2016), esp. pp. 105-106

handNote.p: Annotations in a cursiva Anglicana in the margins of ff. 45v, 51v, 66v, 125r, 170r by a scribe who R. M. Thomson also identifies in Cambridge, Peterhouse, MS 109 and Cambridge, Peterhouse, MS 150

listBibl.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse, Cambridge (Cambridge: D.S. Brewer, 2016), esp. pp. 105-106

decoNote.p: Puzzle initial with additional flourishing at the opening of the volume on f. 1r and at the beginnings of occasional other texts throughout the volume. Flourished initials, e.g., 275v in red and blue at the major and minor divisions of the texts.
Inital letter of each line of the capitula list on ff. 1r-9r written in alternate red and blue 'lombardic' capitals.

decoDesc.decoNote: Line fills of red minims in the capitula list on ff. 1r-9r.

note.p: R. M. Thomson recorded annotations in Middle English in a cursiva Anglicana in the margins of ff. 45v ('Nota Elmam'), 51v ('Lok wel'), 66v ('Nota Ryde ... ... ...'), 125r ('Scharp lok þis'), 170r ('Lo Robyn') by a scribe who R. M. Thomson also identifies in Peterhouse MS 109 and Peterhouse MS 150. Peterhouse MSS 109 and 150 are more extensively annotated by this scribe and Thomson cautiously suggests that he may be Ralph Holbeche (Venn:ACAD no number, search 'Holbeche') who was a fellow of Peterhouse in 1335, Master of Peterhouse c. 1345-?1349, and probably died c. 1373-1374.

listBibl.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse, Cambridge (Cambridge: D.S. Brewer, 2016), esp. pp. 59-60, 90, 105-106

binding.p: 18th-century binding. Undecorated parchment cover over thin pasteboards. Six sewing stations tanglible as slightly raised bands on spine. Description of the contents of the volume written in ink on the spine in an 18th century hand, now almost completely erased. Small printed paper label fixed to spine bearing the shelfmark designation '178'.
Head and tail bands wrapped in cream, blue, and yellow yarn mostly lost or rolled inside the back ?due to abrasion.

The left pastedown is paper and contains:
'James 178' in pencil
A list of some of the main textual items in the volume including:
Tabula cum Comto Mag.i Johannis de Sto Paulo see pag 19
a Richardo phlebotomia 81
Do de signis 86
Do de febribus 166
anathema 295
Summa Richardi 312
Do de ... diebus 395
de pulsibus 397
Questiones Salernitanae
The inside right cover is a blank leaf of medieval parchment.
The volume has blue and green thread bookmarks sewn into the outer margin of the opening leaves of a new text; some of these bookmarks have been lost or badly damaged.
Dimensions (L x W x D): 290 x 205 x 95
Stored in a grey archive box with "PETERHOUSE" written on the box in pencil and a printed label '178' fixed to the box with an adhesive.

origin.origDate: Written in the 14th century, or perhaps late 13th century.
origin.origPlace: Written in the Low Countries, or perhaps England.
origin.p: Date and location of production assigned based on palaeographical, decorative, and biographical details.

listBibl.bibl: M. R. James, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1899)
R. M. Thomson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse, Cambridge (Cambridge: D.S. Brewer, 2016)

provenance.p: Perhaps once owned by Ralph HolbecheHolbeche, Ralph (d. c. 1373-1374), former Master of Peterhouse. Peterhouse MS 178 has annotations in Middle English in a cursiva Anglicana in the margins of ff. 45v ('Nota Elmam'), 51v ('Lok wel'), 66v ('Nota Ryde ... ... ...'), 125r ('Scharp lok þis'), 170r ('Lo Robyn') by a scribe who R. M. Thomson also identifies in Peterhouse MS 109 and Peterhouse MS 150. Peterhouse MSs 109 and 150 are more extensively annotated by this scribe and Thomson cautiously suggests that he may be Ralph Holbeche (Venn:ACAD no number, search 'Holbeche') who was a fellow of Peterhouse in 1335, Master of Peterhouse c. 1345-?1349, and probably died c. 1373-1374.

listBibl.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse, Cambridge (Cambridge: D.S. Brewer, 2016), esp. pp. 59-60, 90, 105-106

acquisition.p: The precise date of acquisition is unknown, but the manuscript was certainly at Peterhouse by 1418 as it is recorded in the 1418 inventory of the Peterhouse library. The early 15th-century inventory of the library is preserved in a document now known as the Registrum vetus ('The Old Register'). The Registrum vetus was begun in 1418 by a single scribe, and subsequent donations to the library were added by other members of the College throughout the 15th century. The reference to Peterhouse MS 178 occurs on p. 17 of the Registrum vetus where it is recorded as part of the original inventory of 1418 by the main scribe of the Registrum. The entry in the Registrum vetus for MS 178 is as follows: 'Liber magistri Ricardi experti in qualibet parte medicine --- Incipit in 2o fo lapis in penultimo de albedine. The manuscript has retained the codicological form it had in 1418 as the secundo folio (f. 2r) and penultimate leaf (f. 310r keywords match those in the extant manuscript 'lapis' and 'de albedine' respectively.

recordHist.source: This catalogue uses M. R. James, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1899) and draws extensively on R. M. Thomson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse, Cambridge (Cambridge: D.S. Brewer, 2016). Readers are encouraged to consult both catalogues for further information about this manuscript.

availability.p: Researchers should note that Peterhouse's western European medieval manuscripts are housed at Cambridge University Library (CUL). Scholars who wish to consult Peterhouse manuscripts should contact the Manuscripts Reading Room at CUL to arrange their visit; all CUL admissions procedures will apply. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library. For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

custEvent.p: Recorded as no. 219 in the Ecloga Oxonio-Cantabrigiensis by Thomas James (1600).
Recorded as no. 1881 in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697)
Peterhouse MS 178 was MS 1.8.2 in the older '3 figure' shelfmark system once used in the library of Peterhouse.
